dialogue.speaker: Bot
dialogue.message: Let's dive into anime, I'm excited to share its rich history with you!

dialogue.speaker: Human
dialogue.message: Oh I am interested to know a little more, it's one of my husband's favorite genres

dialogue.speaker: Bot
dialogue.message: That's awesome! Anime has been around since 1917, and its unique art style really took off in the 60s with Osamu Tezuka's works.

dialogue.speaker: Human
dialogue.message: Wow, I didn't realize it was that old.  I thought it was more like the 1970's or 1980's when it started.

dialogue.speaker: Bot
dialogue.message: Yeah, it's had a long evolution, but the 60s were a pivotal time, and Osamu Tezuka is often called the "God of Manga" for his influence on the style.

dialogue.speaker: Human
dialogue.message: Are there any original works still in circulation from 1917

dialogue.speaker: Bot
dialogue.message: Sadly, many early anime works have been lost over time, but some fragments and short films from the 1910s and 1920s have survived and are preserved in archives and museums in Japan.

dialogue.speaker: Human
dialogue.message: I'm glad they have been able to find a way to preserve what they could

dialogue.speaker: Bot
dialogue.message: Me too! It's wonderful that efforts have been made to save these pieces of history, and now they can be studied and appreciated by new generations of anime fans.

dialogue.speaker: Human
dialogue.message: I'm sure anime is very different now than it was even during the pivot time

dialogue.speaker: Bot
dialogue.message: Totally! The style, themes, and technology have all evolved significantly since the 60s, and modern anime often incorporates computer-generated imagery and diverse storytelling.

dialogue.speaker: Human
dialogue.message: Tell me more about Osamu Tezuka

dialogue.speaker: Bot
dialogue.message: Osamu Tezuka is a legend! He's often credited with creating the modern manga and anime style, and his works, like Astro Boy and Kimba the White Lion, are still beloved today.

dialogue.speaker: Human
dialogue.message: Oh, I didn't know Astro Boy was originally an anime?!

dialogue.speaker: Bot
dialogue.message: Astro Boy was actually one of Tezuka's earliest and most influential works, first published as a manga in 1952 and later adapted into an anime series in 1963.

dialogue.speaker: Human
dialogue.message: Wow.  I'm completely mind blown at the moment!  I assume there's still original mangas somewhere in circulation?

dialogue.speaker: Bot
dialogue.message: Tezuka's original manga artworks and manuscripts are indeed preserved and showcased in museums and exhibitions in Japan, including the Osamu Tezuka Museum in Takarazuka.

dialogue.speaker: Human
dialogue.message: It's too bad you have to travel all the way to Japan to experience that bit of history.

dialogue.speaker: Bot
dialogue.message: Although, some of Tezuka's works have been translated and published internationally, so you can still experience his artistry and storytelling through books and online archives.

dialogue.speaker: Human
dialogue.message: When was the first anime film?

dialogue.speaker: Bot
dialogue.message: The first anime film is a bit disputed, but the oldest surviving anime film is "Namakura-gatana" (The Dull Sword), a short film from 1917, which is also considered one of the earliest anime works.
